column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) Wikinews interviews several meteorologists about the prognosis for Cyclone Phailin as it approaches land in the Bay of Bengal at 190 km/h, and the Indian government's preparedness for the storm given past deaths caused by cyclones in the area.

#Summary2=(human2) In two interviews, experts discuss the potential threats of Cyclone Phailin's impact in the Bay of Bengal area, which, if it follows the patterns of previous cyclone events, will pose a significant threat to the inhabitants of that region due to heavy rains and potential flooding, which may lead to significant fatalities and damages.

#Summary3=(human3) Wikinews asks seven experts if Cyclone Phailin will begin to lose strength as it surges over land–to which all experts confirm that it will become weaker–and if the Indian government is prepared for the tropical cyclone–to which Richman, Snow, Titley, and Morissey express that they do not know and Saravanan, Zhang, and Knight respond that the Indian government is prepared.

#Summary4=(human4) A group of experts responds questions about the severity of Cyclone Phailin and the Indian goverment's preparedness, they give responses indicating that the cyclone will lose strength once it is over land but that it is still dangerous, and they mostly decline to comment explicitly on the Indian government's preparedness, but praise the evacuation mandates.

#Summary5=(human5) This interview focuses on questions related to Cyclone Phailin, particularly its forecasted decline in strength as it makes landfall, as well as the preparations of the Indian Government for dealing with the Cyclone, which include mandatory evacuations of people living in coastal areas, in a region with a history of cyclone related death and damages.
#Text=Wikinews interviews meteorological experts on Cyclone Phalin
#Text=File photo of interviewee David Titley .
#Text=Image : David Titley .
#Text=Cyclone Phailin has winds that have been measured at 200 km / h , as it surges over land will it begin to lose strength ?
#Text=Yes , all tropical cyclones are driven by high heat content waters .
#Text=Once a storm moves over any appreciably sized piece of land , the moisture source is removed and the storm begins to dissipate .
#Text=As of the last advisory , T C Phailin has winds of 190 kilometers per hour and has moved inland , headed on a northwest track .
#Text=That is a Category 3 storm .
#Text=The forecast is for a continued decline in strength to a tropical storm within 24 hours and a tropical depression within 36 hours .
#Text=However , there will be very heavy rains and flooding along its path .
#Text=Yes , it will loose strength steadily as more and more of this swirling system moves from being over ocean to being over land .
#Text=This occurs for two reasons :
#Text=As it moves over land , it is cut off from the source of energy driving the storm [ which is ] the evaporation of water from the warm sea surface ;
#Text=Increased friction - the ocean surface is much , much smoother than the land surface .
#Text=Tropical cyclones are sustained by a form of energy called latent heat , which is released by moisture evaporated from the ocean that condenses to form rain .
#Text=As tropical cyclones make landfall , this energy source is cut - off and they rapidly lose strength as they move over land .
#Text=Yes , the Cyclone is almost certain to lose strength as it surges over land .
#Text=Cyclones gather their strength through scraping moisture and heat from warm ocean water that it is not the case over land .
#Text=In the mean time , much stronger friction over land quickly reduces their strength .
#Text=Yes .
#Text=All tropical cyclones lose strength once they make landfall .
#Text=However , they can remain dangerous storms due to very heavy rains and subsequent landslides , and river flooding .
#Text=Phailin 's winds will rapidly weaken as it pushes inland .
#Text=Once Cyclone Phailin comes on shore it will immediately begin to lose strength .
#Text=However , and this is important , it still will contain lots of rainfall making flooding an almost certainty .
#Text=File photo of interviewee R Saravanan .
#Text=Image : R Saravanan .
#Text=A previous cyclone in 1999 in the Bay of Bengal area of India left 10,000 people dead .
#Text=Is the Indian government well prepared to deal with this cyclone ?
#Text=I have not followed that aspect of the societal response for the present storm .
#Text=However , historically , there have been several events that should cause a societal response .
#Text=Hopefully , we all learn from past mistakes .

#Text=The history of strong cyclones and death in the region is notable , with at least 5 large cyclone events in the past 35 years with 10,000 and as many as 300,000 people killed , millions left homeless and estimated damages as high as US $ 10 billion .
#Text=I do n't have enough information to answer this question , one way or the other .
#Text=From all the press reports that I have read , the Indian government appears to have taken the threat of Cyclone Phailin very seriously indeed .
#Text=The government has been much more pro-active in preparing for this cyclone than in the past .
#Text=The forecasts of cyclone track and intensity have been fairly accurate .
#Text=Mandatory mass evacuations have been carried out , which is essential to minimize loss of life in these situations .
#Text=Unfortunately , extensive property damage is bound to occur even with the best preparation .
#Text=My knowledge of the responsiveness of the Indian government to this storm is purely from the cyber space .
#Text=I heard that they orchestrated the largest people evacuation to a natural disaster in Indian history .
#Text=This shall be applauded given the size and strength of Phailin .
#Text=I visited the damaged area of the 1999 storm near Bhubaneshwar in the summer of 2012 for an invited symposium and summer school on tropical cyclones [ ... ] sponsored by the Indian government .
#Text=Given the living standard and residence of people living near the coastal areas in this region , the evacuation is certainly necessary and essential to save lives .
#Text=I can not comment directly on how the Indian government was prepared for this cyclone .

#Text=However , the news reports ( BBC etc. ) were very encouraging in that the authorities were reportedly making strenuous efforts to evacuate the population from near the coast and areas that are prone to flooding .
#Text=Water is the main killer in these storms .
#Text=From all reports that I have seen , the government was well prepared for this cyclone .
#Text=For this question I do n't know the ' preparedness ' of the Indian gov't to deal with this .
